page.title: 02COMMUNICATIONS
page.content:
{Warrington as a route centre
Warrington has been an important area concerning transport since Roman times. It was the furthest point west where the River Mersey could be bridged. The first important road in our region was the Roman road which went through Warrington to Hadrian's Wall. This has always been the major road through the town. In 1831 a railway line was built joining Warrington with the Liverpool/Manchester railway and by 1846 the town was an important station on the main north/south line from Carlisle to Birmingham (LNWR). Waterways have been important in the east/west movement of goods, chiefly between Liverpool and Manchester.
